content.description: Sit start this problem and top it out! The crack features constrictions, handrails and slopers, and technical feet.
content.location:
About 90 feet north (upslope toward Sheep's Nose) from

Two Shakes

.

60 feet east of

Two Shakes

lies this boulder.  This problem faces the

Two Shakes

corridor.

content.description: A quality training problem, this one goes completely horizontal for 20 feet before the crux topout.  Your abs will be screaming in two shakes of a lamb's tail!  Sit-start the problem on the west side of the cave/corridor.  Right hand is pinching a large crystal, left hand on a sharp crimp/pinch on the lip. At the sit-start, your right hip will be against a boulder. Slap, pinch, heelhook and jam for the length of the roof to the awkward handjam topout.
content.protection: A pad is optional but bring tape.
content.location: This area is about 800 feet east (crosslope) of Sleeping Rock and 150 feet west of a large boulder with a two bolt toprope anchor that protects a 20 foot vertical seam/lieback.

content.description: Climb any of three distinct lines on the south face of the southern boulder of the two that comprise what's being called "Two Shakes" here.
content.location: All three lines are about the same quality, left, right, and center.

content.description:
Maybe 50' to the right of

Two Shakes

(right direction given as climber's right when looking up at Sheep's Nose formation) is another boulder with a single problem in the left-leaning crack. Work up the crack and top out through a careful rock-up to crystal pinches.
content.protection: Short, yes, but multiple pads to protect against spill into rocks, burned tree-matter, and razor-sharp, Spanish diggers. Use caution on the slab downclimb, and try not to even touch the burnt-up widowmaker tree off the backside.

pathTokens: Sleeping Rock aka Sheep's Nose Bouldering
